awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Using eco-evolutionary interactions to understand forest responses to environmental change
awd_abstract_narration:
Trees take a long time to grow and begin producing seeds, which means they have long generation times. Therefore, it has been thought that the main way they could survive rapidly changing climates is by spreading into areas that are more suitable before they die out in areas that are becoming less suitable.  However, tree species may also harbor a substantial amount of genetic diversity among individual trees within a populations, which may allow them to adapt to changing conditions on short time frames (50-100 years). This research will test this idea using computer models developed using information from real forest sites. If trees species can adapt quickly, this could influence how forests are managed and how we predict forests will change in the future. This project will also support the research of an early career scientist, provide research training to students, including those from under-served populations, in the use of computer simulations for biology, and provide outreach to the public.   

This project uses a multi-species individual-based modeling approach to examine how heritable variation in demographic responses to climate may influence how forests respond when climates shift.  These responses include changes in tree species ranges and local forest composition. The researchers will modify the forest simulator SORTIE-ND to allow parameters determining how temperature and precipitation affect tree demography to differ between individuals and be passed to offspring with various degrees of heritability. Traditional simulations that assume all individuals of a species are the same will be compared to simulations that allow adaptation to changing temperature and rainfall over 90 years. If heritable environmental responses can substantially affect forest responses to rapid environmental change, this would greatly affect our understanding of the role eco-evolutionary processes will play in future forest dynamics. It would suggests that models need to take these responses into account, and that measuring the magnitude of potential responses to selection is a key empirical need.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

The objective of this project was to investigate the role that evolution in the responses of trees to temperature or precipitation could play in forest responses to environmental change. To do this, we updated a forest simulation model that allows one to track the growth and survival of individual trees with behaviors fit to species found in California?s Sierra Nevada mountains, and to allow individual trees to differ in their climate responses. We are in the process of further updating it to allow seedlings to inherit those climate responses from their parents.

Intellectual Merit:

If evolution can alter responses to climate change over <100 year timespans, this would mean that much greater attention needs to be paid to genetic variation in trees? climate responses when making predictions. So far, we have completed analyses of the expected responses of Sierra Nevada forests to projected climate change without evolution. We found that the warming that is predicted to occur over the next century will favor denser forests and the increased abundance of certain heat-and-drought tolerant tree species such as black oak and Jeffrey pine. Climate change scenarios that differed in degree of warming and precipitation changes showed more similar effects to one another than to the ?no climate change? scenario. While the predictions could be seen as an optimistic result ? simulated forests did not collapse due to climate change alone ? it should be noticed that increased density of trees combined with hotter, drier summer conditions could increase the risk of large wildfires, which are already an increasing problem in the western US.

Broader Impacts:

Funding for this projected helped to train one female lab assistant (who has now gone on to graduate school at UC Santa Barbara) and one PhD student in ecological modeling techniques. Several presentations on preliminary results have been given at scientific conferences, and the paper detailing the results described above has been submitted for publication. While the model has intitally been set up for the Sierra Nevada, the model framework allowing evolutionary responses can be adjusted to fit any forest type. The code will be made available through the SORTIE-ND website for other researchers to use. Better understanding of the role of genetic variation in forest responses to climate may help to target management actions that will support forest sustainability.
